issues.title: what numbers to report in a publication
issues.body: I have now run my 8000+ genes through Hyphy (using BUSTED; thanks for pointing me in the right direction) and have found a number of instances with significant diversifying positive selection. Now I am not quite sure what value I should report in a paper. From the original publication on BUSTED I gather that the p-value and omega3 from the unconstrained model would be useful. Would it be useful to also report the proportion? And if there is no significant selection found, would I also report these numbers (in a supplement)? Many thanks for your help!

issues.title: Misclassification of relaxed genes as positive (intensified) genes
issues.body:
Hello,

I simulated about 11263 genes under relaxation by the Evolver program in PAML using a phylogeny that I am studying, and ran RELAX on these simulated genes. In particular I did no vary omega>1 and omega=1, but increased omega0 in the foreground.

At a p value cutoff of 0.05, RELAX found 5752 genes with k<1 (true positive rate = 51% ). However, I notice that there are 1657 simulated genes showed p < 0.05 and k>1. A closer inspection showed that the majority of these genes (1492) have parameter estimates of omega0 = 0 for both the foreground and the background clades. Therefore, RELAX has misinterpreted 16.57% of relaxation as positive selection. 

In my real data, I found that about half the genes with k>1 have parameter estimates of omega0 = 0. So I'm not sure if they should indeed be considered relaxed.

I am wondering if this is caused by the search constraints of omega0? What happens if you don't allow it to be 0? 

I am attaching 6 example simulated datasets for you to look at.

[sims.tar.gz](https://github.com/veg/hyphy/files/1606216/sims.tar.gz)

Best Regards,
Ray

issues.title: Memory usage in creation, computation and optimization of a likelihood function
ReadFromString(), ReadFromFile() convert species names when reading a nexsus format
issues.body:
Hi Dear Team,

I've noticed that when reading data from a string / file in nexus format, the names of the species are converted to be with upper case:

For example, for following code:

```
fas_string = ">a1
A
>a2
C
>a3
A
>a4
A";
DataSet fas_dataset = ReadFromString(fas_string);

nex_string = "#NEXUS
begin data;
	dimensions ntax=4 nchar=1;
	format datatype=dna missing=? gap=-;
matrix
a1       
A
a2    
C
a3      
A
a4  
A
;
end;";
DataSet nex_dataset = ReadFromString(nex_string);


fprintf(stdout, "fas_dataset: ", fas_dataset, "\n"); // debug
fprintf(stdout, "nex_dataset: ", nex_dataset, "\n"); // debug
```

Yields:

```
fas_dataset: 4 species:{a1, a2, a3, a4};
Total Sites:1;
Distinct Sites:1
nex_dataset: 4 species:{A1, A2, A3, A4};
Total Sites:1;
Distinct Sites:1
```

This is also the case when reading the data from a file using `ReadFromFile()`

Is there any particular reason for that?

Thanks!
Keren

pull_requests.title: Addition of binaryML model, allowing optimization of states frequencies
pull_requests.body:
Added a new function to libv3/models/frequencies.bf a new function `frequencies.ML.binary` based on the function `frequencies.ML.protein`.

Added a new file under directory libv3/models/binary by the name empirical.bf, based on the file libv3/models/proteins/empirical.bf.

Added a test /scratch300/halabikeren/hyphy/tests/hbltests/libv3/models/binaryML.bf, an input data for the text /scratch300/halabikeren/hyphy/tests/hbltests/libv3/data/binary.fas.

issues.title: Turn message.log off by default
issues.body: It may be advisable to have message.log files turned off by default; whenever you spawn MPI jobs on the cluster that run a while, you end up with megabytes of log files ••per node**.

issues.title: RELAX with branch specific equilibrium frequencies
issues.body:
Hello,

Sorry to revisit an old issue which remained unresolved. I hope it was ok to start a new one.

1. I want to test for relaxed selection on some branches while simultaneously assigning separate equilibrium nucleotide frequencies to the **same** branches.
2. If possible, I would like to do this for two branches in the same tree i.e. test for relaxation with different equilibrium frequencies on multiple sets of "test" branches (different from background).

Can you guide me on how to accomplish this? What I have in mind is similar to Wertheim et al (MBE 2015) in the case of endosymbionts.

Thanks!
Saurabh Mahajan

issue_comments.body:
Hi Sergei, 

I agree, perhaps "bug" was the wrong word. I initially uncovered this behavior when I was setting up a model, in which, like HKY85F, I already input frequencies into the matrix. I couldn't find much documentation about the 3rd argument (MULTIPLY_BY_FREQS), so I simply put in a vector of ones for the second Model() argument, just to fully ensure that my matrix would stay the same and not be crossed with any additional frequencies. It was not clear to me the second argument directly corresponds the frequency vector used in the pruning algorithm, so this would explain all the behavior I saw. 

However, this does raise another point - is there a way in HyPhy to obtain ML estimates for the frequency parameters, rather than using empirical, or empirically-derived, frequencies? I would like to have a set-up where the frequency parameters can be obtained over the course of likelihood optimization as opposed to fixed before-hand from the empirical frequencies.

Thanks!
-Stephanie

Thanks so much for your response. In addition, say I do intend for equal branch lengths to be used in my simulation, will it then be the case that siteScale (as used in my working code) scales the HKYs (as used in my working code) substitution matrix at each site?

I deeply apologize for my ceaseless silly questions but every response I have received thus far have gone a long way towards helping me in my research.

Many thanks,

Hello Sergei,

Very helpful. I deeply appreciate your response.

Hello Sergei,

How does one simulate data with branch-to-branch rate variation? I need to introduce variation on a selected set of (terminal) branches on a given tree.

Thanks in advance,
hyphyInfant.

Hello Sergei,

How does one simulate data with branch-to-branch rate variation? I need to introduce variation on a selected set of (terminal) branches on a given tree.

Thanks in advance,
hyphyInfant.

Hello Sergei,

The recommended approach worked.

Many thanks,
hyphyInfant.

Hello Sergei,

Thanks for replying. My supervisor was able to show me a way to code it. And it looks like it is working perfectly. The method he showed me is to define my model and tree and say I need to constrain the rate category on branches 1 and 2 on a tree defined as mytree, I wrote:

```
 mytree.branch1.rate = myrate;
 mytree.branch2.rate = myrate;
```

Do you agree?

Thanks a lot,
hyphyInfant.

issues.title: RELAX optimization failed
issues.body:
Hi,
I've encountered an optimization error (below) and I'd appreciate any advice on how to set a "starting point" for whatever parameter RELAX is referring to (maybe omega?).  My debug messages suggest that line 195 of RELAX.bf is causing the issue. The input files are attached.

Thanks,
Daniel

This issue has been resolved by introducing 'volatile' commands into the HBL parser. Basically, anything that has an inline variable definition that could change between calls (a matrix or a dictionary or a string with variable substitutions via backquotes) is now **NOT** compiled into an internal representation, but rather re-parsed from the command string in every call. 

The fix is in https://github.com/nlhepler/hyphy/commit/671a6687e6c76bea57fa81a5afb9960c77d59e99

Hi hyphyinfant,

Because the FASTA format does not allow you to specify the alphabet of the sequences (e.g. nucleotides vs amino acids), HYPHY will try to automatically guess it based on the frequency distribution of letters (e.g. DNA/RNA alignments should not contain  too many not ACGT/U letters). 

When you have a single alignment column, this algorithm can be easily duped: site3 and site6 are determined to be DNA data, and all others -- protein data.

`concatenate` will take the alphabet of the ''first'' data filter as given and discard all the arguments which have a different alphabet (there should be something about that written to ''messages.log''). This explains the differences you see between `allSitesP` and `allSitesD`.

If you want to force HyPhy to treat data as proteins, you can use a non-standard macro that HyPhy understands when reading files. Add the line 

```
$BASESET:BASE20
```

at the beginning of your FASTA string, like so:

```
 DataSet site3 = ReadFromString(" $BASESET:BASE20\n>Specie_1\nA\n>Specie_2\nC\n>Specie_3\nG\n>Specie_4\nT\n>Specie_5\nA\n>Specie_6\nC\n>Specie_7\nG\n>Specie_8\nT\n>Specie_9\nN\n>Specie_10\nY");  
```

Hi CJY,

A few small points to add to Konrad's list

FDR procedures **estimate** something about the distribution of p-values under the null using the p-values you get from the tests. This makes two assumptions: that many (if not most) the the data come from the null, and that the p-values obtained from different tests are directly comparable. Neither assumption is particularly appropriate for MEME
1. The test is generally conservative, i.e. you have to simulate data with dN/dS = 1 on a subset of branches to hit nominal p-values. For real data you either have strong conservation or positive selection, so truly neutral data are rare. This will likely skew your q-value estimates to be more conservative than needed.
2. When you start comparing p-values derived from different genes, you are mixing apples and oranges. Genes have different information content, i.e. MEME will have more or less power to detect the same effect size based on the number of sequences, divergence levels, tree shapes, etc. I am not sure what this will do to q-value estimation, but probably nothing good.
3. Consider the following thought experiment. You have a fixed number of sequences N (say 100) and because MEME derives power from a single site (i,e. its power is a function of N), say the minimum p-value you can realistically see if 10<sup>-5</sup>. Now as you start analyzing more and more genes, FDR or any other sequential rejection procedure will almost surely return an empty list of selected sites when the number of genes becomes large enough. In other words, the more data you get the less power you have to detect selection. This goes back to what Konrad was saying about how stringent you want to be, but you either have to keep driving the p-value down, or accept that the more tests you, the more false positives you will have, i.e. you control the **proportion** of false positives, but not the number.

Hi jmbono,

I see where you are coming from, but I think in this case you should be fine just reporting q-values or expected false positives from FUBAR for each gene. A correction over multiple genes would be appropriate if you were asking the question `Is there evidence of episodic selection somewhere in a given gene?`. BS-REL, FUBAR, and MEME should not be used to answer this question, because they deliver branch- or site- level answers and combining them into gene-level answers would both lose power and be a misuse of the methods (even though some [published papers](http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2013/10/16/molbev.mst198.short)  have done just that to my chagrin). If you **do** want to ask a gene-level question, we have a method that we are going to write-up and publish soon to do just that.

So I would simply report the results for individual genes but avoid making claims that evidence of selection at a site/branch is a formal hypothesis test for selection on the gene as a whole. Basically, BS-REL, FUBAR, and MEME were all designed with the implicit assumption that you have already answered the former question positively. 

Hope this makes sense.

HI hyphyinfant,

`siteRates` is reset to the appropriate value on line 42 of the linked file. Changing its value will automatically propagate across the models which depend on it, hence you don't need to redefine them with hardcoded constant values.

If you want to use branches of constant lengths, then you could replace `t` with `siteRates` in the rate matrix definition, but if you wanted to hit a particular branch length (e.g. 0.1) you would have to calculate the value that `siteRates` would have to assume, so that the branch length of the corresponding HKY85 model evaluated to the required value.

See http://www.hyphy.org/w/index.php/BranchLength for some background

Hi Vinny,

I updated BranchSiteREL.bf a few more times yesterday; it now outputs a different version of the .json file from the commit I references yesterday. See if you can load the JSON generated using the current version (https://raw.githubusercontent.com/veg/hyphy/master/res/TemplateBatchFiles/BranchSiteREL.bf).

If you e-mail me (to make sure I have your current e-mail address), I'll send you a Dropbox link to the manuscript draft.

Sergei

Hi Rigers.

The issue is fixed; you should be able to run PRIME on datamonkey. Thanks for letting us know!
Please confirm, and close the issue if you are able to complete analyses.

Sergei

Hi Rigers,

Can you please supply the job ID for the crashed job?

Sergei

Hi hyphyinfant,

The ordering of rows will be based on vector-based ordering of rate categories. For example if you have two category variables, the first one (X) with N rates and the second one (Y) with M rates (see below on how you determine which one is first and which one is second), then the ordering will be as follows

```
X = 0, Y = 0
X = 0, Y = 1
...
X = 0, Y = M-1
X = 1, Y = 1,
...
X = N-1, Y = M-1
```

The ordering of category variables is essentially the order in which they were defined in the rate matrices (not the same as the order they were defined in the code), which is a bit confusing. You can use

```
GetString (info, lf_id, -1)
```

where `info` will be a dictionary with a key _Categories_ which stores a matrix of strings ordering the variables. So if you have

```
info["Categories"]  -> {{"Y","X"}}
```

then **Y** will be the first variable in the ordering vector, etc.

Sergei

Sorry for not responding sooner, Vinny.

I published the 2.2.1 release (including a GUI for OS X) with numerous big fixes including this one (I hope). 

Please confirm and close the issue if it's been resolved.

Hi John,

Apologies for a slow response time.

You can use set an environment variable to prevent HyPhy from unrooting the tree. Note, however, that under time reversible models the relative lengths of the two daughter branches of the root are not estimable (only the total length is).

Please take a look at [this code example](https://github.com/spond/hyphy-support/blob/master/code_examples/issue214.bf) which takes an alignment with a tree in it (rooted or unrooted). You can test it with [the hiv.seq file from this directory](https://github.com/spond/hyphy-support/tree/master/code_examples/data).

Sergei

Hi hyphyinfant,

Sorry for missing this post (I just noticed it). Typically you would do this by using a local model (which has branch-level parameters), and then setting them to whatever values you want, Did you have a particular model in mind?

You can also do it in HyPhy using preprogrammed analyses (you do not need to program anything), see [this tutorial](https://github.com/veg/hyphy-tutorials/tree/master/selection)

Best,
Sergei

Hi there,

You can get separate **rate** (synonymous and non-synonymous) estimates for each site, using for example, FUBAR (discussed in the HyPhy tutorial I link in the previous message). You can parse the output .csv file for each file to get those values. I would recommend you use those values: synonymous for dS an non synonymous for dN.

HTH,

Hi yifeiren07,

If you are primarily interested in recombination, I would run the full sequences (more signal there).
However, if your ultimate objective is to run a selection screen and correct for the confounding effect of recombination, I would only use CDS (because that's what you will be analyzing with codon-based methods).

Sergei

Hi Stephanie,

I don't think the behavior is buggy; the issues here are subtle.
1. It is expected that models 1 and 2 will produce the same likelihood (they are equivalent)
2. Model 3 is specified incorrectly. The equilibrium frequencies of HKY85F are actually F4 (which is how you set it up). However, HyPhy will populate the root of the tree with the **declared** frequencies (F1), which are not normalized to sum to 1 (and won't be automatically), So, the distribution of the unobserved characters for the pruning algorithm at the root will be invalid and lead to an invalid likelihood function
3. Model 4 is exactly like Model 3, except you don't multiply the rate matrix by 1.

Sergei

Hi Taojerry,

GABranch has been deprecated in favor of branch-site REL. Please see https://github.com/veg/hyphy-tutorials/tree/master/selection#use-absrel-to-find-lineages-which-have-experienced-episodic-diversification on a simple tutorial about how to run it in HyPhy.

Hi Gemma,

Curiously, we have already implemented something like this for http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25294947 

I coded up a simple example; it fits a general (non-reversible) two-state model to each branch in the **rooted** tree, as well as a vector of frequencies at the root. (https://github.com/spond/hyphy-support/blob/master/code_examples/issue223.bf and the example data in the same repo)

Note that the most general form of the two state model only has TWO parameters (not three, as in your example).

```

NRM = {
 {*,r01}
 {r10,*}
};

```

The time is confounded with the rates, and the equilibrium frequencies are determined as 

```

pi_0 = r01 / (r01 + r10);
pi_1 = r10 / (r01 + r10);

```

Sergei

Hi wayne1210,

Spidermonkey can only detect associations between **co-varying** positions, because it looks at the co-occurrence of substitutions along tree branches. I am not sure what you mean by `associations between invariant positions and mutations`: is it that change at position X is associated with LACK of change at position Y?

Sergei

Hi irum2014,

I am afraid I can't help you without more specifics. Please provide these data:
1. Which type of sliding window analysis: is it the standard analysis in HyPhy?
2. What are you trying to visualize?

Sergei

Hi wayne1210,

You could use Spidermonkey to analyze different subtypes of the virus in the same run that way you will capture the substations which you call "polymorphisms" in a single subtype. 

Sergei

Hi irum2014,

This analysis outputs a CSV file, where for each sliding window you will have a row with all parameter estimates recorded. You can then visualize it in R, Excel, etc (they all read CSV files). May I ask, what are you trying to estimate over sliding windows? If I know this, I may be able to help you understand which columns in the CSV file contain the information you need.

Sergei

Hi ghgarcia59,

The power of MEME is that you don't have to segment your data -- if positive selection occurred anywhere in time (assuming it's strong enough to be detectable), you will be able to find it, and then use exploratory lineage mapping to see where on the tree it falls. Datamonkey.org will do it for you.

Hence my suggestion is to analyze all the clones jointly.

Sergei

Hi Gemma,

Your expression for the branch length is correct (n_r10 and not n_r0 for the last term). I have not used INDELible, so I don't really know what it expects in terms of input, and what sort of model parameterizations are standard for it. 

The model I sent you estimates two parameters per branch (the "time", and the frequencies), but they are not directly reported in n_r01 and n_r10. n_r01 = t \* freq (1), and n_r10 = t \* freq (0). Therefore it's OK for the product to get above 1. Since the script outputs freq (0) and freq (1) you can get the rate out of the raw values of n_rij parameters.

Hope this helps,
Sergei

Hi Greg,

I scripted a simple analysis for you to do just that; the dN and dS are estimated based on the entire tree/gene (pooled over branches and sites) using the MG94xREV model with CF3x4 frequency estimator.

https://github.com/spond/hyphy-support/blob/master/code_examples/issue229.bf

Sergei

Hi Jubilox,

Are you referring to the implementation of BS-REL on datamonkey.org? If so, could you please provide a link to the result page of BS-REL where you see this behavior?

Sergei

Hi Jubliox,

Datamonkey ran the analysis with the user tree. Because one of the branches experienced a length "explosion", the tree looks wrong. If you click on the nexus file linked to the result page, you can see the tree used by hyphy, in the newick format, in the Hyphy block. 

Sergei

Moving the alignment stuff out of batchlan2 should significantly ease the burden of reading this diff, with an added bonus of making this code more findable.
There's also some random CMakeLists.txt cleanup in here too. Mostly because we only support compilation by GCC (otherwise OpenMP doesn't work (clang forbids C++ and OpenMP)).
Also, Sergei, I haven't tested building with Xcode, and my changes to CMAKE_{C,CXX}_COMPILER might do something bad there. ~ shrug ~
If you saw DO NOT MERGE, there was a minor C preprocessor thinko, which is now fixed.

Yea, I was about to do something similar until I spied the line about _OPENMP actually containing the specification date. Granted, I had to go into the OpenMP specification to discover this fact, and test it using a small C++ program.

The specification writers made an idiotic decision: they infer data sharing attributes, and mandate that explicitly stating data sharing attributes for variables which have had their data sharing attributes inferred is an error, even if the attributes agree. Then they had the audacity to change what gets automatically inferred, leaving the programmer with no way to program compatibly between OpenMP versions. Instead, we have to use this version-check kludge. What's the saying? "Generous on input, strict on output"? FAIL

Dear CJY,

Thanks for the question - these are important issues that ought to get more publicity. For a good discussion of the thinking behind FDR in this context, see this blog post by Nicolas Lartillot: http://bayesiancook.blogspot.com/2014/04/fdr-and-single-gene-experiment.html

To add to what Nicolas said, it makes sense to think about what one wants when reporting a list of sites:

Do you want to be reasonably confident that the list contains absolutely _no_ false positives? In that case, a traditional multiple test correction controlling the family-wise error rate is the right thing to do, and will often lead you to report an empty list. This is as it should be: if you really think a single false positive invalidates the entire list, you need to err on the side of caution and in many cases an empty list will be the only way to do this. Success!

On the other hand, it seems very unlikely that this is what most people want. Typically, we all accept that biology is noisy and that false positives will occur - if we are willing to tolerate a list of sites that contains false positives (provided we know roughly how many items on the list are likely to be false positives, even though we don't know _which_ ones they are), we can produce a much more informative list. This is what FDR is for.

Now, we could go with a q-value threshold of 0.05, producing a list that is roughly 95% true positive and 5% false positive, but that is still very conservative and will still often result in an empty list. Do we really want to be that stringent? In the end it depends on what you want to use the list for, but for most purposes we can imagine a list containing 80% true positives (q-value threshold of 0.2) or even 50% true positives (q-value threshold of 0.5) being useful. So I would pick a less stringent q-value threshold (guided by the purpose of the study) and report the list along with an estimate of the expected number of false positives on the list (the q-value threshold will give an upper bound; the sum of the actual q-values on the list gives a direct estimate of the number of false positives).

As for the second question, what you are proposing would be an ad hoc approach that may have some validity to it, but would be hard to interpret as it does not give a direct answer to a specific question. I am especially concerned that simply aggregating the answers to a set of site-level questions is unlikely to be a good way to answer a gene-level question. The main problem is that it is not clear which question you have in mind with "if there are significantly more episodic selection in a specific gene family". Do you mean more sites with at least given strength of episodic selection? Or stronger episodic selection on average (you would need to specify what you mean by "average" - the presence of purifying selection complicates things)? Or more time spent (on average per site) under positive selection? Etc. etc: there is an endless variety of questions one can come up with, any of which arguably captures something of what you're getting at. The beauty of the probabilistic approach is that we can build a model to answer any of these questions directly, but first you have to decide what the question really _is_.

Hope this helps,
Konrad Scheffler

Dear Sergei,

Yes, now I am working in a new batch file and actually following that line: 
1. I compute a global replacement matrix that is the mean of our input site-specific matrices.
2. Given a user-specified tree and the global matrix, I compute the global likelihood and I optimize the tree. This optimized tree will be used for the next steps.
3. Now I work site by site. I compute the likelihood for each site using its site-specific matrix and the optimized tree (this tree is obtained in the previous step and it is the same for all sites..), with this likelihood I perform the ASR. So, I do not optimize a tree per site..
4. The final likelihood is the sum of the likelihoods per site.

Does it make sense for you?
If you want to see the final code I can send you, but I do not want to disturb you too much.. Also given all the help you provided us lastly, if you want to participate in a paper derived from this work as a coauthor, it is possible. Let me know.
Many thanks for your great help! :-))

Best,
Miguel
